question: An infant or small child's airway can be occluded if it is overextended or overflexed because:
answers: the tongue is proportionately small and can fall back into the throat.
the back of the head is flat, which prevents a neutral position.
the occiput is proportionately large, and the trachea is flexible.
he or she has a long neck, which makes the trachea prone to collapse.
correctAnswers: the occiput is proportionately large, and the trachea is flexible.
selectedAnswer: the occiput is proportionately large, and the trachea is flexible.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: An infant's blood pressure typically increases with age because:
answers: blood pressure directly corresponds to body weight.
the infant's total blood volume decreases with age.
as the infant gets older, his or her blood vessels dilate.
his or her normal heart rate usually increases with age.
correctAnswers: blood pressure directly corresponds to body weight.
selectedAnswer: as the infant gets older, his or her blood vessels dilate.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Breathing is often more difficult in older adults because the:
answers: elasticity of the lungs decreases.
surface area of the alveoli increases.
diaphragm and intercostal muscles enlarge.
overall size of the airway decreases.
correctAnswers: elasticity of the lungs decreases.
selectedAnswer: elasticity of the lungs decreases.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Factors that contribute to a decline in the vital capacity of an elderly patient include all of the following, except:
answers: increased stiffness of the thoracic cage.
decreased residual volume.
increased surface area available for air exchange.
a loss of respiratory muscle mass.
correctAnswers: increased surface area available for air exchange.
selectedAnswer: decreased residual volume.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Infants are often referred to as "belly breathers" because:
answers: their diaphragm does not receive impulses from the brain.
their intercostal muscles are not functional.
their rib cage is less rigid, and the ribs sit horizontally.
an infant's ribs are brittle and are less able to expand.
correctAnswers: their rib cage is less rigid, and the ribs sit horizontally.
selectedAnswer: their rib cage is less rigid, and the ribs sit horizontally.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: In late adults, the amount of air left in the lungs after expiration of the maximum amount of air:
answers: decreases, resulting in widespread collapsing of the alveoli and impaired diffusion of gases.
increases, which hampers diffusion of gases because of the stagnant air that remains in the alveoli.
remains unchanged because the lungs have become accustomed to years of breathing pollution.
decreases, which increases diffusion in the lungs and causes an accumulation of carbon dioxide.
correctAnswers: increases, which hampers diffusion of gases because of the stagnant air that remains in the alveoli.
selectedAnswer: increases, which hampers diffusion of gases because of the stagnant air that remains in the alveoli.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: The anterior fontanelle fuses together between the ages of:
answers: 7 and 14 months.
3 and 4 months.
6 and 8 months.
9 and 18 months.
correctAnswers: 9 and 18 months.
selectedAnswer: 9 and 18 months.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: The average pulse rate of persons between 19 and 40 years of age is typically:
answers: 70 beats/min.
80 beats/min.
60 beats/min.
90 beats/min.
correctAnswers: 70 beats/min.
selectedAnswer: 70 beats/min.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: The pulse rate of a child from ages 6 to 12 years is approximately:
answers: 60 to 100 beats/min.
100 to 150 beats/min.
90 to 140 beats/min.
70 to 120 beats/min.
correctAnswers: 70 to 120 beats/min.
selectedAnswer: 70 to 120 beats/min.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: When assessing an 80-year-old patient in shock, it is important to remember that:
answers: it is common to see a more significant increase in heart rate than what would be expected in younger adults.
the patient's cardiac output is able to increase by nearly 200% in response to the decrease in perfusion.
age-related changes in the cardiovascular system might make the patient less able to compensate for decreased perfusion.
in older adults, it is especially common to observe a significant decrease in heart rate in response to shock.
correctAnswers: age-related changes in the cardiovascular system might make the patient less able to compensate for decreased perfusion.
selectedAnswer: age-related changes in the cardiovascular system might make the patient less able to compensate for decreased perfusion.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Which of the following are noticeable characteristics of a 9-month-old infant?
answers: Knows his or her name, can walk without any assistance
Responds to his or her name, crawls around efficiently
Walks without help, becomes frustrated with restrictions
Places objects in the mouth, pulls himself or herself up
correctAnswers: Places objects in the mouth, pulls himself or herself up
selectedAnswer: Responds to his or her name, crawls around efficiently
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Which of the following is not a common factor that would affect a 75-year-old patient's vital signs?
answers: Overall health
Medical conditions
Increased weight
Medications
correctAnswers: Increased weight
selectedAnswer: Increased weight
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Which of the following statements regarding an infant's vital signs is correct?
answers: An infant's heart rate generally ranges between 70 and 110 beats/min.
An infant's normal heart rate increases by 10 beats/min each month.
An infant's normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler's normal body temperature.
By six months of age, an infant's normal tidal volume is 2 to 4 mL/kg.
correctAnswers: An infant's normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler's normal body temperature.
selectedAnswer: An infant's normal body temperature is typically higher than a preschooler's normal body temperature.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Which of the following statements regarding toddlers and preschoolers is correct?
answers: Toddlers and preschoolers have well-developed lung musculature, even though they have less lung tissue.
Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.
Muscle mass and bone density decrease in toddlers and preschoolers because of increased physical activity.
The normal respiratory rate in toddlers and preschoolers is between 12 and 20 breaths/min.
correctAnswers: Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.
selectedAnswer: Toddlers and preschoolers commonly experience upper respiratory infections because of the loss of passive immunity.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Why does the incidence of diabetes mellitus increase with age?
answers: Increased physical activity, increased food intake, and increased insulin production
Decreased physical activity, increased weight gain, and decreased insulin production
Decreased food intake, decreased weight gain, and decreased blood sugar levels
Decreased physical activity, increased weight gain, and decreased blood sugar levels
correctAnswers: Decreased physical activity, increased weight gain, and decreased insulin production
selectedAnswer: Decreased physical activity, increased weight gain, and decreased insulin production
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: Why do middle adults commonly experience financial concerns?
answers: They are typically receiving social security and must budget with a fixed income.
They are preparing for retirement but must still manage everyday financial demands.
The majority of middle adults still have small children who live at home with them.
Most people in the middle adult age group have chronic illnesses and cannot work.
correctAnswers: They are preparing for retirement but must still manage everyday financial demands.
selectedAnswer: They are preparing for retirement but must still manage everyday financial demands.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: With increasing age, the heart must work harder to move the blood effectively because:
answers: diastolic blood pressure decreases.
the arteries dilate significantly.
the blood vessels become stiff.
the blood thickens as a person ages.
correctAnswers: the blood vessels become stiff.
selectedAnswer: the blood vessels become stiff.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: You are assessing a 13-month-old female who is running a fever and has been vomiting. While you are performing your physical examination on this child, you will most likely find that she:
answers: has bulging fontanelles secondary to severe dehydration.
is unable to track your movements with her eyes.
will readily allow you to separate her from her mother.
responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.
correctAnswers: responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.
selectedAnswer: responds to her name but is fearful of your presence.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: You are dispatched to a call for a 4-month-old infant with respiratory distress. While you prepare to take care of this child, you must remember that:
answers: the infant's proportionately small tongue often causes an airway obstruction.
an infant's head should be placed in a flexed position to prevent obstruction.
assisted ventilations in infants often need to be forceful to inflate their lungs.
small infants are nose breathers and require clear nasal passages at all times.
correctAnswers: small infants are nose breathers and require clear nasal passages at all times.
selectedAnswer: small infants are nose breathers and require clear nasal passages at all times.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)

question: You suspect that a 75-year-old man has internal injuries after he fell and struck his ribs and abdomen on the corner of a table. When assessing and treating an injured patient of this age, you must recall that:
answers: his ability to physiologically compensate for his injury might be impaired due to an inability to increase cardiac output.
functional blood volume in patients of this age steadily increases due to increased production of red blood cells.
blood pressure is usually adequately maintained because the blood vessels of older people can contract easily.
it is not uncommon to observe heart rates in excess of 150 beats/min in elderly patients with internal injuries.
correctAnswers: his ability to physiologically compensate for his injury might be impaired due to an inability to increase cardiac output.
selectedAnswer: his ability to physiologically compensate for his injury might be impaired due to an inability to increase cardiac output.
title: AHE190 04 13790 - SU25 - Emerg Medical Tech. (scope)
